repnme.cdata!:
Bolivia - Sustainability of the National
            System of Protected Areas Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Sustainability of the
            National System of Protected Areas Project in Bolivia were
            as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk
            to global environment outcome was substantial, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was moderately satisfactory. Lessons learned included: (1)
            any new operation should keep the vision of a long-term
            strategic framework provided by the Master Plan. Planning
            instruments for the long-term management of protected areas
            must be clearly articulated to national development plans
            and agendas in order to incorporate sustainable biodiversity
            management as a key element for national and local
            development; (2) although the establishment and operation of
            the protected areas trust fund through the Foundation for
            the Development of the National System of Protected Areas
            has met the project goals, the National System of Protected
            Areas (SNAP)'s financial sustainability is still an
            important bottleneck on Bolivia's protected areas
            management. At project's closing, the majority of
            funding was still coming from international donors; (3) the
            implementation of the Master Plan in a next phase should
            give priority to the following aspects: i) supporting
            institutional development at various levels (national,
            departmental and municipal); (ii) supporting administrative
            decentralization without hindering the development of the
            central government; (iii) respecting Bolivia's
            particular cultural and ethnic diversity; (iv) ensure that
            conservation and sustainable use initiatives result in local
            benefits, and (v) relate natural resource management to
            rural development; (4) sustainable biodiversity and natural
            resources management models for protected areas and their
            buffer zones were developed and implemented by communities
            with assistance from the National Protected Areas Service;
            (5) the participatory process of preparation of the
            protected areas management plans was not sufficient, by
            itself, to secure the ownership and full understanding of
            the proposed conservation strategies by stakeholders; (6)
            the project did not succeed in taking all the steps needed
            to articulate, measure and inform the Management Committees
            and other stakeholders regarding the indicators of
            biodiversity and of the current and projected future
            resource use patterns by communities in each Protected Area;
            and (7) the success of the project depended greatly on the
            continuity of the project technical staff.

repnme.cdata!:
Bolivia - Sustainability of the National
            Systems of Protected Areas Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the first phase of the
            Sustainability of the National System of Protected Areas
            Project for Bolivia. Its development objective is to ensure
            the sustainable management of the National System of
            Protected Areas (SNAP) by establishing and strengthening: a)
            legal, institutional, and policy frameworks; b) management
            capacity at the protected area and central levels; and c)
            SNAP finanacing mechanisms. Phase I will also identify the
            gaps in representativity of Bolivian ecosystems within the
            current protected areas, and propose adjustments to SNAP to
            expand its coverage to all relevant ecosystems. There are
            five project components. The first aims to strengthen the
            regulatory agency's policy, planning, and management
            capacities, and its ability to operate autonomously. The
            second component aims to strenthen the planning and
            managment capacities of the protected areas, and increase
            local participation and inter-institutional coordination.
            The third component prepares and approves the Protected
            Areas law, and amends cross-sectoral laws and regulations.
            The fourth component establishes and capitalizes a dedicated
            trust fund to provide recurrent cost financing for protected
            areas. The fifth component consolidates and complements
            ongoing efforts in resource managmeent and monitoring in
            protected areas and their buffer zones.
